message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a positive VDRL and FTA-ABS, indicating syphilis infection. Penicillin is the recommended treatment for primary and secondary syphilis. Azithromycin and ceftriaxone are used to treat gonorrhea and chlamydia infections, which are not indicated in this case. Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus infections. No treatment is not indicated for syphilis infection.

Acyclovir is used for herpes infections, and azithromycin and ceftriaxone are used for treatment of gonorrhea and chlamydia. No treatment is not appropriate for a positive syphilis test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive VDRL and FTA-ABS tests indicate a diagnosis of syphilis. The most appropriate management of this patient is penicillin, which is the standard treatment for early syphilis. Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus infection, and azithromycin and ceftriaxone are used to treat gonorrhea and chlamydia infections. No treatment is not appropriate for someone with a positive syphilis test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive VDRL and FTA-ABS tests suggest syphilis, and the lesion on the penis is a common symptom of primary syphilis. Penicillin is the standard treatment for syphilis. Acyclovir is used for herpes virus infections, which may have similar symptoms as syphilis but would not cause a positive VDRL or FTA-ABS. Azithromycin and ceftriaxone are used for treatment of chlamydia and gonorrhea, which would not cause a positive VDRL or FTA-ABS. No treatment is not indicated for syphilis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive results of VDRL and FTA-ABS tests suggest a diagnosis of syphilis. Penicillin is the treatment of choice for syphilis, and therefore, option (D) is the most appropriate management for this patient. Acyclovir is used for the treatment of herpes virus infections, while azithromycin and ceftriaxone are used for the treatment of sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia and gonorrhea. No treatment indicated is not the correct option because syphilis requires prompt treatment to prevent complications.
